abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is rated
            unsatisfactory. Riots and looting of project facilities
            during the first two years of project implementation
            resulted in the destruction and loss of technical and
            financial information available at the level of implementing
            agencies. Insecurity and political instability thereafter
            prevented continuation of implementation and supervision.
            Thus, for example, there are no data available to indicate
            that livestock productivity was raised by expanding animal
            health services under this project. The students being
            trained in Senegal did not complete their curriculum before
            the project closed. The looting of warehouses belonging to
            the National Federation of Central African Herders (FENC)
            during the riots seriously disrupted distribution of
            veterinary pharmaceuticals, causing increased mortalities of
            livestock and alleged emigration of a number of herds to
            neighboring countries. Civil disobedience and lack of the
            government's timely responses eventually led to the
            closing the project. Project sustainability is uncertain.
            Overall World Bank performance is rated marginally
            satisfactory while Borrower performance is adjudged
            unsatisfactory. However, The Interprofessional Livestock
            Development Fund (FIDE) stands out as a model for the
            organization of financial flows to the livestock sector,
            both from within and outside, from the private sector, and
            from Government, with joint management in which
            professionals have the opportunity to gain control.
